{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = 80,000 Hours | image = | founded_date = October 2011<ref name="80k-history">{{cite web | url = http://80000hours.org/our-mission-and-history | title = Our Mission and History | accessdate = 25 October 2012 | publisher = 80,000 Hours}}</ref> | tax_id = | registration_id = | founder = [[William MacAskill]] and Benjamin Todd | origins = [[Oxford]], England, UK | key_people = | area_served = Worldwide | product = Free, evidence-based career advice | mission = | focus = Social impact coaching | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | subsid = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = We want to change the world by helping millions of people make more difference with their careers.<ref name="80k-slogan">{{cite web | url = http://80000hours.org/our-mission-and-history | title = Our Mission and History | accessdate = 24 October 2012 | publisher = 80,000 Hours}}</ref> | homepage ={{url|80000hours.org/}} | dissolved = | footnotes = | former name = |parent_organization=[https://www.centreforeffectivealtruism.org/ Centre for Effective Altruism]}}
'''80,000 Hours''' is a San Francisco-based organisation that conducts research on the careers with positive social impact and provides career advice. It provides this advice online, through one-on-one advice sessions and through a community of like-minded individuals. The organisation is part of the '''Centre for Effective Altruism'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA-->, affiliated with the [[University of Oxford]] Uehiro Centre for Practical Ethics.<ref name="80k-history" /> The organisation's name refers to the typical amount of time someone spends working over a lifetime.<ref name="80k-faq">{{cite web | url = http://80000hours.org/faq | title = FAQ | accessdate = 29 October 2012 | publisher = 80,000 Hours | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121101064337/http://80000hours.org/faq | archivedate = 1 November 2012 | df = dmy-all }}; {{cite web | url = http://www.euromoney.com/Article/3044777/Impact-investing-the-big-business-of-small-donors.html | title = Impact investing: the big business of small donors | accessdate = 31 October 2012 | publisher = Euromoney }}</ref> It was one of the nonprofits funded by startup accelerator [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]] in 2015.<ref name=yc-techcrunch>{{cite web|url = https://techcrunch.com/2015/08/04/80000-hours/|title = Want To Make An Impact With Your Work? Try Some Advice From 80,000 Hours|date = 4 August 2015|accessdate = 31 October 2015|publisher = [[TechCrunch]]}}</ref>
== Principles == According to 80,000 Hours, some careers aimed at doing good are far more effective than others. On their framework for assessing different career options, the value of a career is regarded as depending on both its potential for impact and on the degree to which it gives the individual better opportunities to have an impact in the future.<ref name="80k-about">{{cite web | url = http://80000hours.org/research | title = Research | accessdate = 17 January 2014 | publisher = 80,000 Hours}}</ref>
The group emphasises that the positive impact of choosing a certain occupation should be measured by the amount of additional good that is done as a result of this choice, not by the amount of good directly done.<ref name="80k-counterfactuals">{{cite web | url = http://80000hours.org/blog/35-the-replaceability-effect-working-in-unethical-industries-part-1 | title = The replaceability effect: working in unethical industries part 1 | author = Sebastian Farquhar | accessdate = 31 October 2012}}</ref> It considers indirect ways of making a difference, such as [[Earning to give|earning a high salary in a conventional career and donating]] a portion of it, as well as direct ways, such as scientific research. The moral philosopher [[Peter Singer]] mentions the example of banking and finance as a potentially high impact career through such donations in his TED Talk, "The why and how of effective altruism," where he discusses the work of 80,000 Hours.<ref name="peter-singer-TED-talk">{{cite web | url = http://www.ted.com/talks/peter_singer_the_why_and_how_of_effective_altruism.html | title = The why and how of effective altruism | author = Peter Singer | accessdate = 27 December 2013}}</ref>
[[William MacAskill]] is the Founder and President of 80,000 Hours,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://80000hours.org/about/meet-the-team/|title=Meet the team|work=80,000 Hours|access-date=4 April 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> the Co-founder and Vice-President of [[Giving What We Can]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.givingwhatwecan.org/about-us/the-team|title=The Team|accessdate=16 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021170844/http://www.givingwhatwecan.org/about-us/the-team|archivedate=21 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and a Research Associate at the Uehiro Centre for Practical Ethics, [[Oxford University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.practicalethics.ox.ac.uk/staff/staff/research_associates/will_macaskill|title=William MacAskill, Research Associate|accessdate=16 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023051515/http://www.practicalethics.ox.ac.uk/staff/staff/research_associates/will_macaskill|archivedate=23 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Criticism == 80,000 Hours has promoted the idea that pursuing a high-earning career and donating a significant portion of the income to cost-effective charities can be an effective philanthropic strategy for some people. [[John Humphrys]] criticised this idea on the [[Today (BBC Radio 4)|BBC Today programme]], saying that people interested in becoming wealthy tend to be selfish and that idealistic young people will become cynical as they age.<ref>{{cite interview | last = Crouch | first = William | last2 = Hislop | first2 = Ian | title= BBC News - Today - Do bankers make the world better? | subjectlink2 = Ian Hislop | others = [[John Humphrys]] |work=Today | date = 22 November 2011 | access-date = 29 October 2012 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_9645000/9645137.stm}}</ref>
This idea was also criticised in the ''Oxford Left Review'', where Pete Mills wrote that lucrative careers perpetuate an unjust system.<ref name="oxford-left">{{cite journal | last = Mills | first = Pete | title = The Ethical Careers Debate | journal = The Oxford Left Review | issue = 7 | pages = 4–9 | date = May 2012 | url=http://oxfordleftreview.com/2012/07/17/olr-issue/ | access-date = 6 August 2014}}</ref> In addition, he argues that because the likelihood of bringing about social change is difficult to quantify, 80,000 Hours is biased toward quantifiable methods of doing good.
Over time 80,000 Hours has deemphasised 'earning to give', in favour of alternative paths like research, advocacy or policy reform, and begun recommending work on problems that are less easily quantified.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://80000hours.org/2015/07/80000-hours-thinks-that-only-a-small-proportion-of-people-should-earn-to-give-long-term/|title=80,000 Hours thinks that only a small proportion of people should earn to give long term - 80,000 Hours|date=2015-07-06|work=80,000 Hours|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-US}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://80000hours.org/articles/cause-selection/|title=A list of the most urgent global issues|work=80,000 Hours|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-US}}</ref>
[[David Brooks (journalist)|David Brooks]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' has criticised the organisation for its [[consequentialism|consequentialist]] approach to altruism and has argued that cultivating altruism is not purely a matter of maximising one's positive social impact.<ref>{{cite newspaper | last = Brooks | first = David | title = How to Produce a Person | newspaper = The New York Times | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/04/opinion/brooks-the-way-to-produce-a-person.html |date=4 June 2013 |page=A25}}</ref>
The [[effective altruism]] movement, of which 80,000 Hours is a part, has been criticised by Ken Berger, the founder of [[Charity Navigator]] for its efforts to objectively compare and prioritise charitable causes, which he believes to be a subjective process that is the responsibility of individual donors.<ref>{{cite journal | title = The Elitist Philanthropy of So-Called Effective Altruism | journal = Stanford Social Innovation Review | url = http://www.ssireview.org/blog/entry/the_elitist_philanthropy_of_so_called_effective_altruism}}</ref> William MacAskill responded to this article justifying the need to figure out which charities do the most good.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ssir.org/articles/entry/what_charity_navigator_gets_wrong_about_effective_altruism|title=What Charity Navigator Gets Wrong About Effective Altruism (SSIR)|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-us}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Earning to give]] *[[Effective_altruism#Room_for_more_funding|Room for more funding]] *[[Applied ethics]] *[[GiveWell]]

{{Hindu philosophy}} '''Ālambana''' ([[Sanskrit]]:आलम्बन), is a Sanskrit noun which variously means – support, foundation, supporting, base, sustaining, cause, reason, basis, or the five attributes of things, or the silent repetition of a prayer, or the natural and necessary connection of a sensation with the cause which excites it, or the mental exercise practiced by the yogis in endeavouring to realize the gross form of the Eternal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sanskrit Dictionary|publisher=Spokensanskrit. de|url=http://spokensanskrit.de/index.php?script=HK&beginning=0+&tinput=alambana&trans=Translate&direction=AU}}</ref>
==Vedic implication==
In [[Indian philosophy]] the word, ''ālambana'', refers to the objective basis of a perception or sensation; according to which philosophy ''Kārana'' (cause) and all attendant emotional conditions are known as ''Vibhavas'' which are of two kinds – a) ''Ālambana'', the personal and human object and substratum, and b) ''Uddipana'', the excitant. ''Ālambana'' may further be divided into ''asraya'' and ''visaya'', [[Radha]] is ''asraya'' and [[Krishna]] is ''visaya''; Radha, as the devotee, experienced greater pleasure than Krishna who remained the object of her veneration.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vaniquotes|url= http://vaniquotes.org/wiki/Vibhava_is_divided_into_the_two_categories_alambana_and_uddipana._Alambana_may_be_further_divided_into_asraya_and_visaya }}</ref> ''Visaya'' is the potential object of a perceptual consciousness, ''ālambana'' is the objective basis which can even be the cause of perceptual or cognition support for a perceptual error.<ref>{{cite book|title=Logic, Language and Reality:Indian Philosophy and Contemporary Issues|author=Bimal Kroshna Matilal|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass|pages=99|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V8SLH7ogB9oC&pg=PA219&dq=alambana&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ItvAU9PuDdeQuASzuIHYAg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=alambana&f=false}}</ref> The [[Nyaya]] school does not consider the object in front to be the ''ālambana'' of the illusory cognition but rather the interfering external element with its own characteristics.<ref>{{cite book|title=Bhamati and Vivarna Schools of Advaita: A Critical Approach|author=Poolasth Soobah Roodurmum|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass|page=54|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=2pU2ZQB2wUYC&pg=PA54&dq=alambana&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ItvAU9PuDdeQuASzuIHYAg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=alambana&f=false }}</ref> The best ''ālambana'' for the ''[[upasana]]'' of [[Brahman]] is [[Om]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Gaudapadakarika|author=Gaudapada|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass|page=296|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Lz08gSuuLQkC&pg=PA296&dq=alambana&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8-HAU8fNNs-l8AWL6IK4Dg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=alambana&f=false}}</ref>
In [[Vedic]] parlance, ''ālambana'' is also known as ''skambha'' i.e. the pillar of strength; God is the pillar of strength;<ref>{{cite book|title=Vedic Philosophy for Himalayan Eco-System Development|author=M.L.Dewan|publisher=Concept Publishing Co.|page=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hebaAAAAMAAJ&q=alambana+vedic&dq=alambana+vedic&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zOvBU8nQEI63uAS5p4HABg&redir_esc=y}}</ref> it is the objective contemplation which lends support to the mind in its travel Godwards.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Wisdom of the Hindus|author=Brian Brown|publisher=Brentanos|page=278|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bLwlAAAAMAAJ&q=alambana+upanishads&dq=alambana+upanishads&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_fjBU7GrJM28uASmtIHAAg&redir_esc=y}}</ref>
==Rasa implication==
In the Indian theory of [[Rasa (aesthetics)|Rasa]], ''Uddipana'' is the excitant or determinant which inflames sentiments or emotions, and ''ālambana'' is that on which the sentiment hangs i.e. ''ālambana'' is with reference to the sentiment which arises as the link between a sentiment and the cause which excites it. In ''Rasa'' process, the nature or object is said to be visibly present before the ''asraya'' as an excitant but the object that arouses emotions is usually imagined by the poet or dramatist; the mere presence of ''vibhava'' impels the configuration of ''Pratibha'' (the intuitive outcome of wisdom or knowledge) to change it in no time.<ref>{{cite book|title=I.A.Richards and Indian Theory of Rasa|author=Gupteshwar Prasad|publisher=Sarup & Sons |pages=92,230|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hmy5cnSbsWYC&pg=PA92&dq=alambana&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uODAU_2XH8Xs8AWJiIGwBg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=alambana&f=false}}</ref> As per the Rasa of Heroic devotion in compassion the enhancing excitants include transitory emotions such as impatience, understanding and happiness, and Krishna in some disguised form is offered by the hero, motivated by kindness, his own body. [[Yuddhisthira]] had made sacrificial offerings to Krishna.<ref>{{cite book|title=Bhaktirasamrtasindhu of Rupa Gosvamin|author=Rupa Gosvami|publisher=Motolal Banarsidass|pages=579–581|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DsRb6gjUa1oC&pg=PA581&dq=alambana+vedic&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ru3BU63-K82XuATh84GoBg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=alambana%20vedic&f=false}}</ref>
==Yogic implication==
With the aid of self-supported yoga or ātmālmbana yoga, [[Ishvara]] can be seen in two ways i.e. dual and non-dual, or can be seen as fourfolded. ''Ālambana'' refers to inner support and [[yoga]] refers to self-discipline; ''ātmālambana yoga'' is the discipline of objectifying the non-self with the aid of the self when the negated-self becomes the object of the self.<ref>{{cite book|title=Paratattvagaonitadarsanam|author=G.S.Murty|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass |pages=174,175|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ig1-enQgyE8C&pg=PA174&dq=alambana&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uODAU_2XH8Xs8AWJiIGwBg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=alambana&f=false }}</ref>
[[Patanjali]] while defining Sleep which is a [[vritti]] of [[Buddhi]], just as the waking state and the dream states are, tells us:
:अभावप्रत्ययालम्बना तमोवर्त्तिर्निद्रा (Yoga Sutra Samādhipada 10)
:"Deep sleep is the absence of all impressions resulting from opacity in that which is mutable in human-beings (citta)."
Here, he has used the word, ''ālambana'', to mean support or based on i.e. absence of impressions is supported / based on inertia.<ref>{{cite web|title=Samadhi pada 10 |publisher=Ashtangayoga.info |url=http://www.ashtangayoga.info/source-texts/yoga-sutra-patanjali/chapter-1/item/abhava-pratyaya-alambana-tamo-vrittir-nidra/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140827022537/http://www.ashtangayoga.info/source-texts/yoga-sutra-patanjali/chapter-1/item/abhava-pratyaya-alambana-tamo-vrittir-nidra/ |archivedate=2014-08-27 |df= }}</ref>
==Buddhist implication==
According to the [[Yogacara]] phenomenology the ''ālambana'' condition, whether immediate direct or remote, means if there exists a dharma it will have a distinct appearance, the mind will sometimes correspond with it (''[[lakshana]]'') for that ''[[dharma]]'' to be cognized and perceptually grasped. This condition leads to the awakening which results in the ending of the eight consciousnesses and replacing them with four enlightened cognitive abilities.<ref>{{cite book|title=Buddhist Phenomenology|author=Dan Lusthaus|publisher=Routledge|pages=500–503|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j0TKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA500&lpg=PA500&dq=alambana&source=bl&ots=KV4dFfAzsT&sig=GRwQCtuiXAQdCTfXc6lYHCm5164&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4NbAU9rpA4b88QWZsIKgCg&ved=0CDoQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=alambana&f=false }}</ref> The Buddhist consider ''ālambana'' as a cause same as ''hetu'', ''samanantara'' and ''adhipati'', they consider it to be the object-condition which is taken as the cause in the production of knowledge and mentals, such as ''citta'' and ''caitta''.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Central Philosophy of Buddhism|author=T.R.V.Murti|publisher=Routledge|page=170|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mmvzSw2igPUC&pg=PA170&dq=alambana&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ItvAU9PuDdeQuASzuIHYAg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=alambana&f=false }}</ref> According to [[Nagarjuna]] there are three motivational contexts of love and compassion viz, ''sattva-ālambana'', motivated by the similarity of one’s self with other selves, ''dharma-ālambana'', motivated by the sameness of psycho-physical elements, and ''ānalambana'' which is not motivated by these two i.e. which is independent of motivational context.<ref>{{cite book|title=Buddhist Critical Superiority|author=Shohei Ichimura|page=81|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=xTW6XNxOxbkC&pg=PA23&dq=alambana&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ItvAU9PuDdeQuASzuIHYAg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=alambana&f=false }}</ref> [[Xuanzang]] in the context of [[Dignāga]]’s statement with reference to the eighth consciousness explains that the seeds or virtualities of the eighth consciousness produce the actual consciousness and also the objective base (ālambana) of actual consciousness.<ref>{{cite book|title=Phenomenology and Indian Philosophy|publisher=SUNY PRESS|page=265|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hCfipfaNM44C&pg=PA265&dq=alambana&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8-HAU8fNNs-l8AWL6IK4Dg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=alambana&f=false }}</ref>

{{ SpecialChars | compact = | special = [[Alchemical_symbols#Unicode|Unicode alchemical symbols]] | fix = Help:Special_characters | characters = alchemical symbols }} [[Image:Alchemical-symbols-1775.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Alchemical symbols in [[Torbern Bergman]]'s 1775 ''Dissertation on Elective Affinities'']] {{For|the [[Unicode block|block]] of characters encoded in Unicode|Alchemical Symbols (Unicode block)}}
'''Alchemical symbols''', originally devised as part of [[alchemy]], were used to denote some elements and some compounds until the 18th century. Although notation like this was mostly standardized, style and symbol varied between alchemists, so this page lists the most common.
==Three primes== According to [[Paracelsus]] (1493–1541), the three primes or ''tria prima'' – of which material substances are immediately composed – are:<ref name="Eric John Holmyard 1990. p.153">Eric John Holmyard. ''Alchemy.'' 1995. p.153</ref><ref>Walter J. Friedlander. ''The golden wand of medicine: a history of the caduceus symbol in medicine.'' 1992. p.76-77</ref>
* [[Mercury (element)|Mercury]] (Mind) <big>☿</big> [[Image:Mercury symbol.svg|28px]] * [[Salt (chemistry)|Salt]] (base matter or body) <big>🜔</big> [[File:Line within circle.svg|25px]] * [[Sulfur]] (Spirit) <big>🜍</big> [[Image:Sulphur.svg|20px]]
==Four basic elements== {{main|Classical elements}} Western alchemy makes use of the Hermetic elements. The symbols used for these are:<ref name="Eric John Holmyard 1990. p.153"/> *[[Air (classical element)|Air]] <big>🜁</big> [[Image:Alchemy air symbol.svg|20px]] *[[Earth (classical element)|Earth]] <big>🜃</big> [[Image:Alchemy earth symbol.svg|20px]] *[[Fire (classical element)|Fire]] <big>🜂</big> [[Image:Alchemy fire symbol.svg|20px]] *[[Water (classical element)|Water]] <big>🜄</big> [[Image:Alchemy water symbol.svg|20px]]
==Seven planetary metals== {{main|Classical planets in Western alchemy|Planets in astrology|Metals of antiquity}}
Seven metals are associated with the seven classical planets, and seven deities, all figuring heavily in alchemical symbolism. Although the metals occasionally have a glyph of their own, the planet's symbol is used most often, and the symbolic and mythological septenary is consistent with Western astrology. The planetary symbolism is limited to the seven [[wandering stars]] visible to the naked eye, and the extra-Saturnian planets [[Uranus]] and [[Neptune]] are not used.
*[[Lead]] dominated by [[Saturn (astrology)|Saturn]] <big>♄</big> ( [[Image:Saturn symbol.svg|20px]] )<ref name="Eric John Holmyard 1990. p.153"/> *[[Tin]] dominated by [[Jupiter (astrology)|Jupiter]] <big>♃</big> ( [[Image:Jupiter symbol.svg|20px]] ) *[[Iron]] dominated by [[Mars (astrology)|Mars]] <big>♂</big> ( [[Image:Mars symbol.svg|20px]] ) *[[Gold]] dominated by [[Sun (astrology)|Sol]] <big>☉</big> <big>☼</big> ( [[Image:Sun symbol.svg|20px]] ) *[[Copper]] dominated by [[Venus (astrology)|Venus]] <big>♀</big> (also: [[Image:Copper symbol.svg|30px]] ) *[[Mercury (element)|Mercury]] (quicksilver) dominated by [[Mercury (astrology)|Mercury]] <big>☿</big> ( [[Image:Mercury symbol.svg|20px]] ) *[[Silver]] dominated by [[Moon (astrology)|Luna]] <big>☽</big> ( [[Image:Crescent.svg|15px]] )
==Mundane elements== [[Image:Squaredcircle.svg|thumb|150px|The Squared Circle: an Alchemical Symbol (17th century) illustrating the interplay of the four [[Classical element|elements]] of matter symbolising the philosopher's stone]] *[[Antimony]] <big>♁</big> [[Image:Antimony-symbol.svg|15px]] *[[Arsenic]] <big>🜺</big> [[Image:Arsenic alchemical symbol.svg|15px]] *[[Bismuth]] <big>🜘</big> [[File:Bismuth Symbol.svg|20px]] *[[Boron]] <big>=</big> *[[Lithium]] [[Image:Stone symbol.svg|20px]] *[[Magnesium]] <big>⊛</big> *[[Phosphorus]] <big></big> *[[Platinum]] <big>☽☉</big> *[[Potassium]] <big></big> *[[Sulfur]] <big>🜏 🜍</big> [[File:Sulfur symbol 1 2.svg|20px]] [[File:Sulphur.svg|20px]] *[[Zinc]] [[File:Zinc-alchemy symbols.png|100px]]
==Alchemical compounds== [[Image:Alchemytable.jpg|200px|thumb|A table of alchemical symbols from [[Basil Valentine]]'s ''The Last Will and Testament'', 1670]] *[[Sal ammoniac]] (Ammonium chloride) <big>🜹</big> <big>*</big> *[[Aqua fortis]] (Nitric acid) <big>🜅</big> <big>A.F.</big> *[[Aqua regia]] (Nitro-hydrochloric acid) <big>🜆</big> <big>A.R.</big> *[[Spirit of wine]] (also called ''aqua vitae'')(Concentrated ethanol) <big>🜈</big> <big>S.V.</big> *[[Amalgam (chemistry)|Amalgam]] (Alloys of a metal and mercury) <big>🝛</big> *[[Cinnabar]] ([[Mercury sulfide]]) <big>🜓</big> *[[Vitriol]] (Sulfates) <big>🜖</big>
==Alchemical processes== [[Image:Alchemy-Digby-RareSecrets.png|250px|right|thumb|An extract and symbol key from [[Kenelm Digby]]'s ''A Choice Collection of Rare Secrets'', 1682]] The alchemical [[magnum opus (alchemy)|magnum opus]] was sometimes expressed as a series of chemical operations. In cases where these numbered twelve, each could be assigned one of the [[Zodiac]] signs as a form of cryptography. The following example can be found in [[Antoine-Joseph Pernety|Pernety's]] 1758 Mytho-Hermetic Dictionary:<ref>Antoine-Joseph Pernety. ''Dictionnaire mytho-hermétique, dans lequel on trouve les allégories fabuleuses des poètes, les métaphores, les énigmes et les termes barbares des philosophes hermétiques expliqués.'' 1758. p.99</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=February 2014}}'''Bandhu''' (1), [[Sanskrit]] for ''friend'' connected with ''bandhan'' or ''ties'' which are the connections that, according to the [[Vedas]] link the outer and the inner worlds. [[Vedas|Vedic]] texts {{which|date=November 2011}} speak, for example, of the 360 bones of the fetus that fuse into the 206 bones of the adult (after the 360 days of the year). Recently, the word has been used in a Song of a Bollywood Feature Film " Cocktail ", Where a Man Calls a girl(Tum hi ho Bandhu)he likes and Rates her as an Angel from the outer world Connected to him. It is used commonly in ''Hindi'' in the sense of "brother". Synonyms: "Hindi", it may mean ''bhai" as in "Twamecha Bandhu, sakha twameva", part of the Krishna stotra, where Lord Krishna is being referred to as "brother". In ''Urdu'' it takes the meaning of ''bhai''.
[[Rajiv Malhotra]] in his book [[Being Different]] describes how 'Bandhuta/Bandhu' is an in-built feature of this universe. In the story<ref>http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-02-29/vintage-wisdom/30341831_1_devas-universe-vedas</ref> [[Prajapati]] attempts to create the Universe keeping Order and Chaos in dynamic balance. His initial attempts fail because they're too 'Jami'/homogenous or too 'Prthak'/different. Finally he gets the combination just-right, by using the principle of 'Bandhuta'/'Bandhu' i.e. binding together dissimilar things by what is common across all things in the entire creation.
As per Dharma traditions 'Bandhuta' exists in all planes/fields connecting them together. Few noteworthy fields are 'Nrittya'/Dance, 'Sangeet'/Music, 'Jyotish'/Astrology, 'Vastu-Shastra', [[Yoga]], [[Ayurveda]]/Medicine.

{{Taxobox | image = | image_caption = | domain = [[Bacteria]] | phylum = [[Proteobacteria]] | classis = [[Gammaproteobacteria]] | ordo = [[Enterobacteriales]] | familia = [[Enterobacteriaceae]] | genus = ''[[Pectobacterium]]'' | species = ''[[Pectobacterium carotovorum|P. carotovorum]]'' | subspecies = '''''P. c.'' subsp. ''betavasculorum''''' | trinomial = ''Pectobacterium carotovorum'' subsp. ''betavasculorum'' | trinomial_authority = | synonyms = *''Erwinia carotovora'' subsp. ''betavasculorum'' *''Pectobacterium betavasculorum'' }} [[File:Pectobacterium Table Beet Slice.jpg|thumb|right|A table beet infected with ''Pectobacterium carotovorum'' subsp. ''betavasculorum''. Note the rings of black vascular tissue colonized by the rotting bacteria.]]
'''Beet vascular necrosis''' and '''rot''' is a soft rot disease caused by the bacterium '''''Pectobacterium carotovorum'' subsp. ''betavasculorum''''', which has also been known as ''Pectobacterium betavasculorum'' and ''Erwinia carotovora'' subsp. ''betavasculorum''.<ref name=Compendium2 /> It was classified in the [[genus]] ''Erwinia'' until genetic evidence suggested that it belongs to its own group;<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dye|first=DW|title=A taxonomic study of the genus Erwinia. II. The "carotovora" group|journal=New Zealand Journal of Science|year=1969|volume=12|pages=81–97}}</ref> however, the name Erwinia is still in use. As such, the disease is sometimes called Erwinia rot today. It is a very destructive disease that has been reported across the United States as well as in Egypt. Symptoms include [[wilting]] and black streaks on the leaves and [[Petiole (botany)|petioles]]. It is usually not fatal to the plant, but in severe cases the beets will become hollowed and unmarketable. The bacteria is a [[generalist species]] which rots beets and other plants by secreting digestive enzymes that break down the [[cell wall]] and [[parenchyma]] tissues.<ref name=Ecology/> The bacteria thrive in warm and wet conditions, but cannot survive long in fallow soil.<ref name=Compendium /><ref name=DescriptionEtiology /> However, it is able to persist for long periods of time in the [[rhizosphere]] of weeds and non-host crops.<ref name=Compendium /><ref name=Ch11Handbook /> While it is difficult to eradicate, there are cultural practices that can be used to control the spread of the disease, such as avoiding injury to the plants and reducing or eliminating application of nitrogen fertilizer.
== Hosts ==
Fodder beets, [[sugar beets]] and fodder-sugar crosses are all susceptible to infection by ''Pectobacterium carotovorum'' subsp. ''betavasculorum''.<ref name=Compendium2>{{cite book |editor1-first=E.D |editor1-last=Whitney |title=Compendium of Beet Diseases and Insects |edition=2nd |year=1986 |publisher=American Phytopathological Society |location=St. Paul, MN }}</ref> Today most beet [[cultivars]] are resistant to the pathogen, however, isolates vary geographically, and some cultivars of beets are only resistant to specific isolates of bacteria. For example, the cultivar USH11 demonstrates resistance to both Montana and California isolates, whereas Beta 4430 is highly susceptible to the Montana isolates but resistant to the California isolate.<ref name=Zidack>{{cite journal|last=Zidack|first=Nina|author2=Barry Jacobsen|title=First Report and Virulence Evaluation of Erwinia caratovora subs. Betavasculorum on Sugarbeet in Montana|journal=Plant Health Progress|year=2001|url=http://www.plantmanagementnetwork.org/pub/php/research/sugarbeet/|accessdate=18 October 2013}}</ref> Other cultivars resistant to California isolates of ''Pectobacterium caratovorum'' subsp. ''betavasculorum'' include Beta 4776R, Beta 4430R and Beta 4035R, but HH50 has been found to be susceptible.<ref name=Zidack />
Breeding for resistance to other diseases such as [[beet yellows virus]] without also selecting for vascular necrosis resistance can leave cultivars susceptible to the pathogen. For example, the use of USH9A and H9B in California’s San Joaquin valley is thought to have led to an epiphytotic (severe) outbreak of disease in the early 1970s.<ref name=WhitneyLewellen>{{cite journal|last=Whitney|first=E.D.|author2=R.T. Lewellen |title=Bacterial Vascular Necrosis and Rot of Sugar Beet: Effects on Cultivars and Quality|journal=Phytopathology |year=1977|volume=67|issue=10|pages=912–916|doi=10.1094/phyto-67-912}}</ref> This was likely because of the limited gene pool used when selecting strongly for resistance to beet yellows virus. Further information on resistant cultivars can be found in the section [[#Management|Management]].
In addition to beets, ''Pectobacterium carotovara'' subsp. ''betavasculorum'' can also infect tomato, potato, carrots, sweet potato, radish, sunflower, artichokes, squash, cucumber and chrysanthemum.<ref name=Compendium2/><ref name=Compendium /><ref name=Ch11Handbook /><ref name=Egypt /> Other [[subspecies]] of ''Pectobacterium carotovora'' can also be [[pathogenic]] to beets. ''Erwinia carotovara'' subsp. ''atroseptica'' is a bacterial soft rot pathogen that is responsible for the disease Blackleg of Potato (''Solanum tuberosum''), and variants of this bacterium can cause root rot in sugarbeets,.<ref name=DeBoer>{{cite journal|last=De Boer|first=Solke H.|title=Blackleg of Potato|journal=The Plant Health Instructor|year=2004|url=http://www.plantmanagementnetwork.org/pub/php/research/sugarbeet/|accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref><ref name=deMendonca>{{cite journal|last=de Mendonca|first=Margarida|author2=M.E. Stanghellini |title=Endemic and Soilborne Nature of Erwinia Carotovora var. atroseptica, a pathogen of Mature Sugarbeets|journal=Ecology and Epidemiology |year=1979|volume=69|issue=10|pages=1093–1099|doi=10.1094/phyto-69-1096}}</ref> This subspecies also has a wide host-range. ''Erwinia carotovora'' var. ''atroseptica'' has been detected in the rhizosphere of native vegetation and on weed species such as ''Lupinus blumerii'' and ''Amaranthus palmeri'' (pigweed).<ref name=deMendonca /> It is thought that the source of inoculums survives on these non-host plants in areas in which it is endemic as well as in the rhizosphere of other crops such as wheat and corn<ref name=deMendonca />
== Symptoms ==
[[File:Pectobacterium Table Beet Stem.jpg|thumb|right|Table beet stem infected with ''Pectobacterium carotovorum'' subsp. ''betavasculorum''. Note entry through a wound.]]
Symptoms can be found on both beet roots and foliage, although foliar symptoms are not always present. If present, foliar symptoms include dark streaking along petioles and viscous froth deposits on the crown which are a by-product of bacterial metabolism.<ref name=Strasbaugh>{{cite journal|last=Strausbaugh|first=Carl A.|author2=Anne M. Gillen|title=Bacterial and yeast associated with sugar beet root rot at harvest in the Intermountain West|journal=Plant Disease|year=2008|volume=92|issue=3|pages=357–363|doi=10.1094/pdis-92-3-0357}}</ref> Petioles can also become necrotic and demonstrate vascular necrosis. When roots become severely affected, wilting also occurs.<ref name=Compendium2/> Below ground symptoms include both soft and dry root rot. Affected vascular bundles in roots become necrotic and brown, and tissue adjacent to necrosis becomes pink upon air contact.<ref name=Compendium2/> The plants that do not die completely may have rotted-out, cavernous roots.
Various pathogens can cause root rot in beets; however the black streaking on petioles and necrotic vascular bundles in roots and adjacent pink tissue help to distinguish this disease from others such as Fusarium Yellows. Additionally, sampling from the rhizosphere of infected plants and serological tests can confirm the presence of ''Erwinia caratovora'' subs.<ref name=deMendonca />
==Disease cycle==
''Pectobacterium carotovorum'' subsp. ''betavasculorum'' is a [[gram negative]], rod bacteria with peritichous [[flagella]].<ref name=Compendium>{{cite book |editor1-first=R.M. |editor1-last=Haverson |title=Compendium of Beet Diseases and Pests |edition=2nd |year=2009 |publisher=American Phytopathological Society |location=St. Paul, MN |pages=58–59}}</ref> For it to enter sugar beet, and thus cause infection, it is essential that there is an injury to the leaves, petioles or crown.<ref name=Compendium /><ref name=Ch11Handbook>{{cite web|title=Sugar Beet Production Guide, Chapter 11: Disease Management, pg 138-139|url=http://www.ianrpubs.unl.edu/epublic/live/ec156/build/ec156-11.pdf|publisher=University of Nebraska – Lincoln Extension, 2013|accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref> Infection will often start at the crown and then move down into the root, and can occur at any point in the growing season if environmental conditions are favorable.<ref name=DescriptionEtiology>{{cite journal|last=Thomson|first=S.V.|title=Beet Vascular Necrosis and Rot of Sugarbeet: General Description and Etiology|journal=Phytopathology|year=1977|volume=67|issue=10|pages=1183–1189|url=http://www.apsnet.org/publications/phytopathology/backissues/Documents/1977Articles/Phyto67n10_1183.pdf|accessdate=17 October 2013|doi=10.1094/phyto-67-1183|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Once the bacteria enters the plant, it will invade the [[vascular tissue]] and cause symptoms by producing plant cell wall degrading enzymes, like pectinases, polygalactronases, and celluases.<ref name=Molecular>{{cite journal|last=Kim|first=H.-S.|title=Pectobacterium carotovorum Elicits Plant Cell Death with DspE/F but the P. carotovorum DspE Does Not Suppress Callose or Induce Expression of Plant Genes Early in Plant–Microbe Interactions|journal=Molecular Plant-Microbe Interactions|year=2011|volume=24|issue=7|pages=773–786|doi=10.1094/mpmi-06-10-0143|pmid=21469936|display-authors=etal}}</ref> This results in discolored or necrotic vascular tissue in the root, and the tissue bordering the vascular bundles will turn reddish upon contact with air.<ref name=DescriptionEtiology /> Following the infection of the vascular tissue, the bacteria reproduce as long as food resources are available, and the root begins to rot.<ref name=DescriptionEtiology /> There is significant variability in the type of rot – it can range from a dry rot to soft and [[wet rot]] – because of the multitude of additional microorganisms that may colonize the damaged tissue<ref name=DescriptionEtiology />
Upon death of the sugar beet, or harvest of the field, the pathogen appears to survive in select living plant tissue like beet roots,<ref name=Compendium /> or volunteer beets.<ref name=Ch11Handbook /> However, it does not appear to survive in sugar beet seeds,<ref name=Compendium /><ref name=DescriptionEtiology /><ref name=Ch11Handbook /> or live in the soil after harvest.<ref name=Compendium /><ref name=DescriptionEtiology /> It is also possible for the pathogen to infect injured carrots, potato, sweet potato, tomato, radish, sunflower, artichokes, squash, cucumber and chrysanthemums;<ref name=Compendium /><ref name=Ch11Handbook /><ref name=Egypt>{{cite journal|last=Saleh|first=O.I. |author2=Huang, P.-Y. |author3=J.-S. Huang|title=Bacterial Vascular Necrosis and Root Rot Disease of Sugar Beet in Egypt|journal=Journal of Phytopathology|year=1996|volume=144|issue=5|pages=225–230–1189|doi=10.1111/j.1439-0434.1996.tb01520.x}}</ref> however, since those are often planted in the same season as sugar beets, they are not likely to be overwintering hosts.
== Environment ==
Injury to the leaves, petioles or crown is mandatory for the [[pathogen]] to gain entry to the host tissue.<ref name=Compendium /><ref name=Ch11Handbook /> Accordingly, [[hail]] damage is correlated with a higher degree of disease outbreak.<ref name=Compendium /> Young plants (less than eight weeks old) are also considered to be more prone to infection<ref name=Compendium /><ref name=Ch11Handbook />
Temperature and availability of moisture are key factors in determining the rate of disease development. Warm temperatures, 25-30 °C, promote rapid disease development.,<ref name=Compendium /><ref name=Ch11Handbook /><ref name=PNDH /> and can result in acute symptoms.<ref name=Compendium /> Symptoms are also reported to appear at temperatures as low as 18 °C, but disease development is slowed;<ref name=DescriptionEtiology /> below that temperature, infections do not develop.<ref name=Compendium /> Excessive water also promotes disease development by providing a more optimal environment for the pathogen,<ref name=PNDH /> and has been shown to be a key factor in augmenting disease outbreak in fields with sprinkler irrigation<ref name=Compendium />
===Agricultural===
The degree of [[nitrogen fertilization]] is highly correlated to robust disease development: it has been shown that sugar beets supplied with excessive or adequate nitrogen are more diseased than sugarbeets with sub-optimal nitrogen levels.<ref name=Compendium /><ref name=Ch11Handbook /><ref name=PNDH /> This is a paradox for farmers because, while increased nitrogen fertilization does increase sugar yield in non-infected sugarbeets, it also increases the severity of the disease if infection takes place. Thus, depending on the severity of infection, yield may go down with increased fertilizer use.<ref name=Spacing&N />
The spacing between plants also impacts the degree of infection: greater in-row spacing results in more diseased roots.<ref name=Spacing&N /> This may be due to the fact that greater spacing promotes faster growth, and hence greater probability of cracks in the crown,<ref name=Ch11Handbook /> or because of the increased amount of nitrogen available per plant.<ref name=Compendium />
Since the pathogen has multiple hosts, it is important for farmers to be wary of other plants in the surrounding area. It is possible for the pathogen to survive in weedy hosts, and can infect injured carrots, potato, sweet potato, tomato, radish, squash, and cucumber.<ref name=Ch11Handbook /><ref name=Egypt /><ref name=PNDH /> Hence, the presence of these plants may increase the supply of inoculum.
===Laboratory===
If the pathogen is cultured in a lab, it can grow on Miller and Schroth media, can use sucrose to make reducing sugars, and can use either lactose, methyl alpha-glucoside, inulin or raffinose to make acids.<ref name=Compendium /> It is also capable of surviving in culture medium sodium levels of up to 7–9%,<ref name=Compendium /> and in temperatures as high as 39 °C.<ref name=PotatovSB>{{cite journal|last=Stanghellini|first=M.E.|title=Serological and Physiological Differences of Erwinia carotovora between Potato and Sugar Beet|journal=Phytopathology|year=1977|volume=67|issue=10|pages=1178–1182|url=https://www.apsnet.org/publications/phytopathology/backissues/Documents/1977Articles/Phyto67n10_1178.PDFf|accessdate=17 October 2013|doi=10.1094/phyto-67-1178|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
== Management ==
Since the bacteria cannot survive in seeds,<ref name=Compendium /><ref name=Ch11Handbook /> the best way to prevent the disease is to ensure that [[vegetatively propagated]] plant material are clean of infection, such that the bacterium does not enter the soil. However, if the bacteria is already present, there are some methods that can be used to lessen the infection.
===Cultural practices===
Because the bacteria readily enter the plant through wounds, management practices that decrease injury to the plants are important to control the spread of the disease.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gallian|first=John J.|title=Management of Sugarbeet Root Rots|url=http://www.cals.uidaho.edu/edcomm/pdf/PNW/PNW0538.pdf|publisher=Pacific Northwest Extension|accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref> Cultivation is not recommended, as the machinery can become contaminated and physically spread the bacteria around the soil. Accidental leaf tearing or root scarring can also occur depending on the size of the crop, allowing the bacteria to enter more individual plants. If [[hilling]] the beets, great care must be taken to avoid getting soil into the crown,<ref>{{cite web|title=UC Pest Management Guidelines|url=http://www.ipm.ucdavis.edu/PMG/r735101111.html|publisher=University of California Agriculture and Natural Resources|accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref> because the pathogen is soil-borne and this could expose the plant to more bacteria, thus increasing the risk of infection.
While most bacteria are motile and can swim, they cannot move very far due to their small size. However, they can be carried along by water, and a significant movement of ''Pectobacterium'' can be attributed to being carried downstream from irrigation and rainwater.<ref name=Ecology>{{cite journal|last=Perombelon|first=Michel CM|author2=Kelman, Arthur|title=Ecology of the soft rot erwinias|journal=Annual Review of Phytopathology|year=1980|volume=18|issue=1|pages=361–387|doi=10.1146/annurev.py.18.090180.002045}}</ref> To control the spread of the disease, limiting irrigation is another strategy. The bacteria also flourishes in wet conditions, so limiting excess water can control both the spread and severity of the disease.
Increased in-row spacing also causes more severe disease. In an infected field, yield decreased linearly when spacing was greater than 15 cm (6 in),<ref name=Spacing&N>{{cite journal|last=Thomson|first=S V|author2=Hills, F. J.|author3=Whitney, E. D.|author4=Schroth, M. N.|title=Sugar and root yield of sugar beets as affected by bacterial vascular necrosis and rot, nitrogen fertilization, and plant spacing|journal=Phytopathology|year=1981|volume=71|issue=6|pages=605–608|url=http://www.apsnet.org/publications/phytopathology/backissues/Documents/1981Articles/Phyto71n06_605.pdf|accessdate=17 October 2013|doi=10.1094/phyto-71-605}}</ref> so a spacing of 6 inches or less is recommended.
The bacteria can also utilize nitrogen fertilizer to accelerate their growth, thus limiting or eliminating the amount of nitrogen fertilizer applied will lessen the disease severity.<ref name=PNDH>{{cite web|title=Sugar Beet (Beta vulgaris)-Bacterial Vascular Necrosis and Rot {Erwinia Root Rot}|url=http://pnwhandbooks.org/plantdisease/sugar-beet-beta-vulgaris-bacterial-vascular-necrosis-and-rot-erwinia-root-rot|publisher=pacific northwest plant disease management handbook|accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref> For example, when fertilizer was applied to an infected field the infection rate per root increased from 11% (with no added nitrogen) to 36% (with 336 kg nitrogen/hectare), and sugar yields decreased.<ref name=Spacing&N />
{| style="float: right; margin-left: 1em;" class="wikitable" |- ! Cultivar !! Resistance !! Source |- | H9 || No || rowspan="4" | <ref name=Spacing&N /> |- | H10 || No |- | C17 || No |- | 546 H3 || Moderate |- | C13 || No || rowspan="7" |<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lewellen|first=R. T. |author2=E. D. Whitney |author3=C. K. Goulas|title=Inheritance of resistance to Erwinia root rot in sugarbeet|journal=Phytopathology|year=1978|volume=68|issue=6 |pages=947–950|url=http://www.apsnet.org/publications/phytopathology/backissues/Documents/1978Articles/Phyto68n06_947.PDF|accessdate=17 October 2013|doi=10.1094/phyto-68-947}}</ref> |- | E540 || No |- | E538 || No |- | E534 || Moderate |- | E502 || Moderate |- | E506 || Yes |- | E536 || Yes |- | C930-35 || Moderate || rowspan="4" |<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lewellen|first=R. T.|title=Registration of sugarbeet germplasm lines C927-4, C929-62, C930-19, and C930-35 with resistance to rhizomania, virus yellows, and bolting|journal=Crop Science|year=2004|volume=44|issue=1|pages=359–361|url=http://www.cabdirect.org/abstracts/20043004196.html?freeview=true|accessdate=17 October 2013|doi=10.2135/cropsci2004.0359}}</ref> |- | C927-4 || Moderate |- | C930-19 || Yes |- | C929-62 || Yes |}
===Resistance===
The bacteria can survive in the rhizosphere of other crops such as tomato, carrots, sweet potato, radish, and squash<ref name=Compendium2/><ref name=Compendium /> as well as weed plants like lupin and pigweed,<ref name=deMendonca /> so it is very hard to get rid of it completely.<ref name=Ecology/> When it is known that the bacterium is present in the soil, planting resistant varieties can be the best defense against the disease. Many available beet cultivars are resistant to ''Pectobacterium carotovorum'' subsp. ''betavasculorum'', and some examples are provided in the corresponding table. A comprehensive list is maintained by the USDA on the Germplasm Resources Information Network.<ref>{{cite web|title=Germplasm Resources Information Network|url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/desc.pl?49076|publisher=United States Department of Agriculture|accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref> Even though some genes associated with root defense response have been identified, the specific mechanism of resistance is unknown, and it is currently being researched.<ref>{{cite web|last=Smigocki|first=A C|title=Molecular Approaches To Pest And Pathogen Resistance in Sugar Beet|url=http://www.ars.usda.gov/research/projects/projects.htm?ACCN_NO=419874&fy=2012|publisher=united states department of agriculture agricultural research service|accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref>
===Biological control===
Some [[bacteriophage]]s, viruses that infect bacteria, have been used as effective controls of bacterial diseases in laboratory experiments. This relatively new technology is a promising control method that is currently being researched. Bacteriophages are extremely host-specific, which makes them environmentally sound as they will not destroy other, beneficial soil [[microorganisms]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Duffy|first=B|title=Biological control of bacterial diseases in field crops|journal=Symposium on Biological Control of Bacterial Plant Diseases|year=2006|pages=93–98|url=http://pub.jki.bund.de/index.php/MittBBA/article/viewFile/709/644..#page=93|accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref> Some bacteriophages identified as effective controls of ''Pectobacterium carotovorum'' subsp. ''betavasculorum'' are the strains ΦEcc2 ΦEcc3 ΦEcc9 ΦEcc14. When mixed with a fertilizer and applied to inoculated calla lily bulbs in a greenhouse, they reduced diseased tissue by 40 to 70%.<ref name=phages>{{cite journal|last=Ravensdale|first=M |author2=T. Blom |author3=J. A. Gracia-Garza |author4=R. J. Smith |author5=A. M. Svircev|title=Bacteriophages of and the control of Erwinia carotovora subsp. carotovora.|journal=Canadian Journal of Plant Pathology|year=2007|volume=29|issue=2|pages=121–130|doi=10.1080/07060660709507448}}</ref> ΦEcc3 appeared to be the most effective, reducing the percent of diseased plants from 30 to 5% in one trial, to 50 to 15% in a second trial.<ref name=phages/> They have also been used successfully to reduce rotting in lettuce caused by ''Pectobacterium carotovorum'' subsp. ''carotovorum'', a different bacterial species closely related to the one that causes beet vascular necrosis.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lim|first=J.A.|author2=Jee S|author3=Lee DH|author4=Roh E|author5=Jung K|author6=Oh C|author7=Heu S.|title=Biocontrol of Pectobacterium carotovorum subsp. carotovorum using bacteriophage PP1.|journal=Journal of Microbiology and Biotechnology|year=2013|volume=23|issue=8|pages=1147–1153|doi=10.4014/jmb.1304.04001|pmid=23727798}}</ref>
While it is more difficult to apply bacteriophages in a field setting, it is not impossible, and laboratory and greenhouse trials are showing bacteriophages to potentially be a very effective control mechanism. However, there are a few obstacles to surmount before field trials can begin.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Frampton|first=Rebekah A.|author2=Andrew R. Pitman|author3=Peter C. Fineran|title=Advances in Bacteriophage-Mediated Control of Plant Pathogens|journal=International Journal of Microbiology|year=2012|doi=10.1155/2012/326452|pmid=22934116|pmc=3426239|url=http://www.hindawi.com/journals/ijmicro/2012/326452/|volume=2012|pages=1–11}}</ref> A large problem is that they are damaged by UV light, so applying the phage mixture during the evening will help promote its viability. Also, providing the phages with susceptible non-pathogenic bacteria to replicate with can ensure there is adequate persistence until the bacteriophages can spread to the targeted bacteria.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jones|first=Jeffrey B |author2=Gary E. Vallad |author3=Fanny B. Iriarte |author4=Aleksa Obradović |author5=Mine H. Wernsing |author6=Lee E. Jackson |author7=Botond Balogh |author8=Jason C. Hong |author9=M. Timur Momol |title=Considerations for using bacteriophages for plant disease control|journal=Bacteriophage|year=2012|volume=2|issue=4|pages=208–214|doi=10.4161/bact.23857|pmid=23531902 |url=https://www.landesbioscience.com/journals/bacteriophage/article/23857/|accessdate=17 October 2013|pmc=3594208}}</ref> The bacteriophages are unable to kill all the bacteria, because they need a dense population of bacteria in order to effectively infect and spread, so while the phages were able to decrease the number of diseased plants by up to 35%, around 2,000 [[Colony forming units|Colony Forming Units]] per milliliter (an estimate of living bacteria cells) were able to survive the treatment.<ref name=phages/> Lastly, the use of these bacteriophages places strong selection on the host bacteria, which causes a high probability of developing [[Antibiotic resistance|resistance]] to the attacking bacteriophage. Thus it is recommended that multiple strains of the bacteriophage be used in each application so the bacteria do not have a chance to develop resistance to any one strain.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Balogh|first=B|author2=Jones, Jeffrey B. |author3=Iriarte, F. B. |author4= Momol, M. T. |title=Phage Therapy for Plant Disease Control|journal=Current Pharmaceutical Biotechnology|year=2010|volume=11|issue=1|pages=48–57|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/ben/cpb/2010/00000011/00000001/art00005|accessdate=17 October 2013 |doi=10.2174/138920110790725302|pmid=20214607}}</ref>
== Importance ==
The disease was first identified in the western states of, California, Washington, Texas, Arizona and Idaho in the 1970s and initially led to substantial yield losses in those areas.<ref name=Spacing&N /> ''Erwinia caratovara'' subsp ''betavascularum'' was not discovered in Montana until 1998. When it first appeared, beet vascular necrosis caused individual farm yield loss ranging from 5–70% in Montana's Bighorn Valley.<ref name=Zidack /> Today, yield losses from the disease are generally infrequent and patchy as most producers plant resistant varieties. Infection rate is generally low if resistant cultivars are chosen; however, warmer and wetter conditions can lead to higher than normal instance of disease<ref name=Zidack />
If infection does occur, bacterial root rots can not only cause economic losses in the field, but also can in storage and processing as well.<ref name=Strasbaugh /> In processing plants, rotten roots complicate slicing and the bacterially-produced slime can clog filters. This is especially problematic with late-infected beets which are generally harvested and processed along with healthy beets. The disease can also lower sugar-content which greatly reduces the quality<ref name=WhitneyLewellen />

revision.text: In [[type theory]], a theory within [[mathematical logic]], the '''bottom type''' is the type that has no values. It is also called the '''zero''' or '''empty''' type, and is sometimes denoted with [[falsum]] (⊥). A function whose return type is bottom cannot return any value. In the [[Curry–Howard correspondence]], the bottom type corresponds to falsity. ==Computer science applications== In subtyping systems, the bottom type is the subtype of all types.{{cite paper | citeseerx = 10.1.1.17.9230 | last = Pierce | first = Benjamin C. | year = 1997 | title = Bounded Quantification with Bottom }} (However, the converse is not true—a [[Subtyping|subtype]] of all types is not necessarily the bottom type.) It is used to represent the return type of a function that does not return a value: for instance, one which loops forever, signals an exception, or exits. Because the bottom type is used to indicate the lack of a normal return, it typically has no values. It contrasts with the [[top type]], which spans all possible values in a system, and a [[unit type]], which has exactly one value. The bottom type is frequently used for the following purposes: * To signal that a function or computation ''diverges''; in other words, does not return a result to the caller. (This does not necessarily mean that the program fails to terminate; a subroutine may terminate without returning to its caller, or exit via some other means such as a [[continuation]].) ** When coupled with the [[Curry–Howard correspondence]] interpretation of bottom as "falsity", this yields a computational interpretation of [[non-constructive logic]] in terms of [[control flow]] operators.{{Cite book | last1=Griffin | first1=Timothy G. | title=Conf. Record 17th Annual ACM Symp. on Principles of Programming Languages, POPL '90, San Francisco, CA, USA, 17-19 Jan 1990 | year=1990 | chapter=The Formulae-as-Types Notion of Control | pages=47–57}} * As an indication of error; this usage primarily occurs in theoretical languages where distinguishing between errors is unimportant. Production programming languages typically use other methods, such as [[option type]]s (including [[tagged pointer]]s) or [[exception handling]]. In ''Bounded Quantification with Bottom'', Pierce says that "Bot" has many uses: # In a language with [[Exception handling|exceptions]], a natural type for the raise construct is ''raise ∈ exception -> Bot'', and similarly for other control structures. Intuitively, Bot here is the type of computations that do not return an answer. # Bot is useful in typing the "leaf nodes" of polymorphic data structures. For example, List(Bot) is a good type for nil. # Bot is a natural type for the "[[null pointer]]" value (a pointer which does not point to any object) of languages like Java: in [[Java (programming language)|Java]], the ''null type'' is the universal subtype of reference types. null is the only value of the null type; and it can be cast to any reference type.{{cite book | chapterurl = http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se5.0/html/typesValues.html#4.1 | title = Java Language Specification | edition = 3rd | chapter = Section 4.1: The Kinds of Types and Values }} However, the null type does not satisfy all the properties of a bottom type as described above, because bottom types cannot have any possible values, and the null type has the value null. # A type system including both Top and Bot seems to be a natural target for [[type inference]], allowing the constraints on an omitted type parameter to be captured by a pair of bounds: we write S<:X<:T to mean "the value of X must lie somewhere between S and T." In such a scheme, a completely unconstrained parameter is bounded below by Bot and above by Top. ==In programming languages== Most commonly used languages don't have a way to explicitly denote the empty type. There are a few notable exceptions. [[Haskell (programming language)|Haskell]] does not support empty data types. However, in [[Glasgow Haskell Compiler|GHC]], there is a flag -XEmptyDataDecls to allow the definition data Empty (with no constructors). The type Empty is not quite empty, as it contains non-terminating programs and the undefined constant. The undefined constant is often used when you want something to have the empty type, because undefined matches any type (so is kind of a "subtype" of all types), and attempting to evaluate undefined will cause the program to abort, therefore it never returns an answer. In [[Common Lisp]] the symbol NIL, amongst its other uses, is also the name of a type that has no values. It is the complement of T which is the top type. The type named NIL is sometimes confused with the type named NULL, which has one value, namely the symbol NIL itself. In [[Scala (programming language)|Scala]], the bottom type is denoted as Nothing. Besides its use for functions that just throw exceptions or otherwise don't return normally, it's also used for [[Covariance and contravariance (computer science)|covariant]] [[Parametric polymorphism#Parametric polymorphism|parameterized types]]. For example, Scala's List is a covariant type constructor, so List[Nothing] is a subtype of List[A] for all types A. So Scala's Nil, the object for marking the end of a list of any type, belongs to the type List[Nothing]. In [[Rust (programming language)|Rust]], the bottom type is denoted by !. It is present in the type signature of functions guaranteed to never return, for example by calling panic!() or looping forever. In [[Ceylon (programming language)|Ceylon]], the bottom type is Nothing.{{cite web | url = https://ceylon-lang.org/documentation/spec/html/typesystem.html#bottomtype | title = Chapter 3. Type system — 3.2.5. The bottom type | website = The Ceylon Language | publisher = Red Hat, Inc. | access-date = 2017-02-19 }} It is comparable to Nothing in Scala and represents the intersection of all other types as well as an empty set. In [[TypeScript]], the bottom type is never.{{Citation|title=TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that compiles to clean JavaScript output|date=2018-02-01|url=https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript|publisher=Microsoft|accessdate=2018-02-01}} ==See also== * [[b:Haskell/Denotational semantics|Haskell's Denotational semantics]] (Discusses the role of Bottom in the denotational semantics of programming languages) *[[Top type]] *[[NaN]] *[[Fail-stop]] == References == {{reflist}} == Further reading == * {{cite book |last=Pierce |first=Benjamin C. |authorlink=Benjamin C. Pierce |title=[[Types and Programming Languages]] |year=2002 |publisher=[[MIT Press]] |isbn=0-262-16209-1}} {{data types}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bottom Type}} [[Category:Data types]] [[Category:Type theory]]

{{Infobox Software | name = ConceptDraw DIAGRAM | logo = [[File:CDDiagram.png|100px|ConceptDraw DIAGRAM Logo]] | screenshot =[[File:Conceptdraw-diagram-12-example-macos.png|400px|Business Process diagram example designed using ConceptDraw DIAGRAM 12 software for macOS]] | caption = ConceptDraw DIAGRAM for macOS. | developer = [[Computer Systems Odessa]] | latest_release_version = 12 | released = {{Start date and age|1999}} | latest_release_date = August 2018 | operating_system = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[macOS]] | genre = Diagramming software | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]] | website =[https://www.conceptdraw.com/products/drawing-tool/ ConceptDraw DIAGRAM] }}
'''ConceptDraw DIAGRAM''' (previously known as ConceptDraw PRO<ref>[http://markets.financialcontent.com/stocks/news/read/36819701/cs_odessa_brings_a_new_level_of_business_processes_visualization_with_conceptdraw_office_v5 CS Odessa Brings a New Level of Business Processes Visualization with ConceptDraw OFFICE v5]. Financial Content, August 21, 2018</ref>) is [[Proprietary software|proprietary]] diagramming software used to create business graphics, including:<ref>[https://thenextweb.com/insider/2013/04/19/conceptdraws-flowcharting-suite-gets-upgraded-with-better-project-handling-organization-and-more/#!rDQev ConceptDraw Flowcharting Suite...].Ken Yeung, TNW, 19 April 2013</ref> [[diagrams]], [[flowcharts]], [[Infographics]], [[data visualization]] for [[Business process modeling|business process models]], [[data presentation]] and [[project management]] [[documentation]].<ref>[http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20080617006509/en/CS-Odessa-Introduces-ConceptDraw-Office---Integrated#.Usw0BtKJzTo The Integrated Solution for Effective Project Management Visualization and Communication] Rebecca Gatanis, BusinessWire, June 17, 2008</ref> It can also be used for creating professional and [[Technical drawing|technical diagrams]], such as: [[Unified Modeling Language|UML]] diagrams, [[Data flow diagram|DFD]], [[Entity-relationship diagram|ERD]], [[computer networks]] topology, [[engineering]] schemes and other technical [[graphic]] formats. The program was developed by CS Odessa in 1999. It is compatible with [[Microsoft Windows]] and [[macOS]] platforms.<ref>[http://tidbits.com/article/6179 Make the Connection with ConceptDraw]. Matt Neuburg, TidBITS, 30 October 2000</ref> Since 2008, it has formed a part of [[ConceptDraw Office]].<ref>[http://www.itbusinessnet.com/articles/viewarticle.jsp?id=459439 Extending Project Efficiency with ConceptDraw Office]. Matthew David, IT Business Net, July 21, 2008</ref> A set of solution add-ons that include collections of task-oriented [[Template (file format)|templates]] and vector [[stencils]] libraries,<ref>[http://www.macworld.com/article/1049667/conceptdraw55.html More than Diagrams] Franklin N. Tessler, Macworld March 3, 2006</ref> have been released for ConceptDraw DIAGRAM, relating to certain industry-specific graphical tasks. The software also contains a set of tools for [[vector graphics]] drawing, along with a built-in [[Slide show|presentation]] mode.<ref>[http://www.channelprosmb.com/article/conceptdraw_pro_9_review ConceptDraw Pro 9 - Artistic Abilities Not Required] James E. Gaskin. ChannelproNetwork, September 17, 2013</ref>
== [[File formats]] ==
* CDDZ - ConceptDraw DIAGRAM document * CDD - ConceptDraw PRO vv9 and earlier document * CDT - ConceptDraw DIAGRAM template * CDX - ConceptDraw XML ConceptDraw DIAGRAM supports its own [[XML]] format, and an embedded [[ScriptBasic|Basic Script language]] for creating complex graphic objects, that change in visual appearance depending on external data received from personal files or from the Internet (Live Objects).<ref>[http://www.pm4girls.elizabeth-harrin.com/2009/03/review-conceptdraw-pro/ Review: ConceptDraw PRO] Elizabeth Harrin, March 03,2009</ref>
== Export/Import == It has import and export roundtrip of the MS Visio file format - can open and save formats that can be used by MS Visio documents (VSD, VDX, and VSDX) users. ConceptDraw DIAGRAM can import both generations of MS Visio stencils (VSS or VSSX) ConceptDraw DIAGRAM supports the round-trip import and export of the [[Microsoft Visio]] 2003 - 2016 file format that is used for MS Visio documents (VSD, VDX, and VSDX formats). ConceptDraw DIAGRAM can import both generations of MS Visio stencils (VSS or VSSX). It can export and import [[MS PowerPoint]] files and a variety of other [[graphics file formats|graphic file formats]]. It can also export files to [[SVG]], [[Adobe PDF]] and [[SWF]].<ref>[http://www.macworld.com/article/1051449/conceptdraw.html ConceptDraw VI adds SVG export, Visio support] Peter Cohen, PCWorld, Jun 20, 2006</ref> ConceptDraw DIAGRAM can import data from other [[ConceptDraw Office]] applications, such as [[ConceptDraw MINDMAP]] and [[ConceptDraw PROJECT]].<ref>[https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2380152,00.asp ConceptDraw Office 2 Review].Linn Samara.PC Mag.com,February 02, 2011)</ref>

In [[probability theory]] and [[statistics]], a '''copula''' is a multivariate probability distribution for which the [[marginal probability]] distribution of each variable is [[Uniform distribution (continuous)|uniform]]. Copulas are used to describe the [[Dependent and independent variables|dependence]] between [[random variable]]s. Their name comes from the Latin for "link" or "tie", similar but unrelated to grammatical [[Copula (linguistics)|copulas]] in [[linguistics]]{{Citation needed|date=March 2015}}. Copulas have been used widely in quantitative finance to model and minimize tail risk<ref name="Banking 2013">{{cite journal|last1=Low|first1=R.K.Y.|last2=Alcock|first2=J.|last3=Faff|first3=R.|last4=Brailsford|first4=T.|title=Canonical vine copulas in the context of modern portfolio management: Are they worth it?|journal=Journal of Banking & Finance|date=2013|volume=37|issue=8|doi= 10.1016/j.jbankfin.2013.02.036}}</ref> and portfolio optimization applications.<ref name="sciencedirect.com">{{cite journal|last1=Low|first1=R.K.Y.|last2=Faff|first2=R.|last3=Aas|first3=K.|title=Enhancing mean–variance portfolio selection by modeling distributional asymmetries|journal=Journal of Economics and Business|date=2016|doi=10.1016/j.jeconbus.2016.01.003}}</ref>
[[Abe Sklar|Sklar]]'s theorem states that any multivariate [[cumulative distribution function#Multivariate case|joint distribution]] can be written in terms of univariate [[marginal distribution|marginal-distribution]] functions and a copula which describes the dependence structure between the variables.
Copulas are popular in high-dimensional statistical applications as they allow one to easily model and estimate the distribution of random vectors by estimating marginals and copulae separately. There are many parametric copula families available, which usually have parameters that control the strength of dependence. Some popular parametric copula models are outlined below.
Two-dimensional copulas are known in some other areas of mathematics under the name ''permutons'' and ''doubly-stochastic measures''.
==Mathematical definition== Consider a random vector <math>(X_1,X_2,\dots,X_d)</math>. Suppose its marginals are continuous, i.e. the marginal [[Cumulative distribution function|CDFs]] <math>F_i(x) = \mathrm{Pr}[X_i\leq x] </math> are continuous functions. By applying the [[probability integral transform]] to each component, the random vector :<math>(U_1,U_2,\dots,U_d)=\left(F_1(X_1),F_2(X_2),\dots,F_d(X_d)\right)</math> has [[uniform distribution (continuous)|uniformly]] distributed marginals.
The copula of <math>(X_1,X_2,\dots,X_d)</math> is defined as the [[cumulative distribution function#Multivariate case|joint cumulative distribution function]] of <math>(U_1,U_2,\dots,U_d)</math>: :<math>C(u_1,u_2,\dots,u_d)=\mathrm{Pr}[U_1\leq u_1,U_2\leq u_2,\dots,U_d\leq u_d] .</math>
The copula ''C'' contains all information on the dependence structure between the components of <math>(X_1,X_2,\dots,X_d)</math> whereas the marginal cumulative distribution functions <math>F_i</math> contain all information on the marginal distributions.
The importance of the above is that the reverse of these steps can be used to generate [[pseudo-random]] samples from general classes of [[multivariate probability distribution]]s. That is, given a procedure to generate a sample <math>(U_1,U_2,\dots,U_d)</math> from the copula distribution, the required sample can be constructed as :<math>(X_1,X_2,\dots,X_d) = \left(F_1^{-1}(U_1),F_2^{-1}(U_2),\dots,F_d^{-1}(U_d)\right).</math> The inverses <math>F_i^{-1}</math> are unproblematic as the <math>F_i</math> were assumed to be continuous. The above formula for the copula function can be rewritten to correspond to this as: :<math>C(u_1,u_2,\dots,u_d)=\mathrm{Pr}[X_1\leq F_1^{-1}(u_1),X_2\leq F_2^{-1}(u_2),\dots,X_d\leq F_d^{-1}(u_d)] .</math>
==Definition==
In [[probability theory|probabilistic]] terms, <math>C:[0,1]^d\rightarrow [0,1]</math> is a ''d''-dimensional '''copula''' if ''C'' is a joint [[cumulative distribution function]] of a ''d''-dimensional random vector on the [[unit cube]] <math>[0,1]^d</math> with [[uniform distribution (continuous)|uniform]] [[marginal distribution|marginals]].<ref name="nelsen">{{Citation |first=Roger B. |last=Nelsen |year=1999 |title=An Introduction to Copulas |location=New York |publisher=Springer |isbn=0-387-98623-5 }}</ref>
In [[Multivariable calculus|analytic]] terms, <math>C:[0,1]^d\rightarrow [0,1]</math> is a ''d''-dimensional '''copula''' if :* <math>C(u_1,\dots,u_{i-1},0,u_{i+1},\dots,u_d)=0 </math>, the copula is zero if one of the arguments is zero, :* <math>C(1,\dots,1,u,1,\dots,1)=u </math>, the copula is equal to ''u'' if one argument is ''u'' and all others 1, :* ''C'' is ''d''-non-decreasing, i.e., for each [[hyperrectangle]] <math>B=\prod_{i=1}^{d}[x_i,y_i]\subseteq [0,1]^d </math> the ''C''-volume of ''B'' is non-negative: :*:<math> \int_B dC(u) =\sum_{\mathbf z\in \times_{i=1}^{d}\{x_i,y_i\}} (-1)^{N(\mathbf z)} C(\mathbf z)\ge 0,</math> ::where the <math>N(\mathbf z)=\#\{k : z_k=x_k\}</math>.
For instance, in the bivariate case, <math>C:[0,1]\times[0,1]\rightarrow [0,1]</math> is a bivariate copula if <math>C(0,u) = C(u,0) = 0 </math>, <math>C(1,u) = C(u,1) = u </math> and <math>C(u_2,v_2)-C(u_2,v_1)-C(u_1,v_2)+C(u_1,v_1) \geq 0 </math> for all <math>0 \leq u_1 \leq u_2 \leq 1</math> and <math>0 \leq v_1 \leq v_2 \leq 1</math>.
==Sklar's theorem== [[File:Gaussian copula gaussian marginals.png|thumb|Density and contour plot of a Bivariate Gaussian Distribution]] [[File:Biv gumbel dist.png|thumb|Density and contour plot of two Normal marginals joint with a Gumbel copula]]
Sklar's theorem,<ref name="Sklar 1959">{{citation | last=Sklar | first=A. | authorlink = Abe Sklar | title=Fonctions de répartition à n dimensions et leurs marges | journal=Publ. Inst. Statist. Univ. Paris | year=1959 | volume=8 | pages=229–231 }}</ref> named after [[Abe Sklar]], provides the theoretical foundation for the application of copulas. Sklar's theorem states that every [[cumulative distribution function#Multivariate case|multivariate cumulative distribution function]] :<math>H(x_1,\dots,x_d)=\mathrm{Pr}[X_1\leq x_1,\dots,X_d\leq x_d]</math> of a random vector <math>(X_1,X_2,\dots,X_d)</math> can be expressed in terms of its marginals <math>F_i(x_i) = \mathrm{Pr}[X_i\leq x_i] </math> and a copula <math>C</math>. Indeed: :<math>H(x_1,\dots,x_d) = C\left(F_1(x_1),\dots,F_d(x_d) \right). </math>
In case that the multivariate distribution has a density <math>h</math>, and this is available, it holds further that :<math>h(x_1,\dots,x_d)= c(F_1(x_1),\dots,F_d(x_d))\cdot f_1(x_1)\cdot\dots\cdot f_d(x_d),</math> where <math>c</math> is the density of the copula.
The theorem also states that, given <math>H</math>, the copula is unique on <math> \operatorname{Ran}(F_1)\times\cdots\times \operatorname{Ran}(F_d) </math>, which is the [[cartesian product]] of the [[Range (mathematics)|ranges]] of the marginal cdf's. This implies that the copula is unique if the marginals <math>F_i</math> are continuous.
The converse is also true: given a copula <math>C:[0,1]^d\rightarrow [0,1] </math> and margins <math>F_i(x)</math> then <math>C\left(F_1(x_1),\dots,F_d(x_d) \right)</math> defines a ''d''-dimensional cumulative distribution function.
==Fréchet–Hoeffding copula bounds== [[File:copule ord.svg|thumb|right|Graphs of the bivariate Fréchet–Hoeffding copula limits and of the independence copula (in the middle).]]
The Fréchet–Hoeffding Theorem (after [[Maurice René Fréchet]] and [[Wassily Hoeffding]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www-history.mcs.st-andrews.ac.uk/Biographies/Hoeffding.html |title=Biography of Wassily Hoeffding |author="J J O'Connor and E F Robertson" |date= March 2011 |publisher= School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of St Andrews, Scotland |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref>) states that for any Copula <math>C:[0,1]^d\rightarrow [0,1]</math> and any <math>(u_1,\dots,u_d)\in[0,1]^d</math> the following bounds hold: : <math>W(u_1,\dots,u_d) \leq C(u_1,\dots,u_d) \leq M(u_1,\dots,u_d).</math> The function '''W''' is called lower Fréchet–Hoeffding bound and is defined as :<math> W(u_1,\ldots,u_d) = \max\left\{1-d+\sum\limits_{i=1}^d {u_i} , 0 \right\}.</math> The function '''M''' is called upper Fréchet–Hoeffding bound and is defined as :<math> M(u_1,\ldots,u_d) = \min \{u_1,\dots,u_d\}.</math>
The upper bound is sharp: ''M'' is always a copula, it corresponds to [[comonotonicity|comonotone random variables]].
The lower bound is point-wise sharp, in the sense that for fixed '''u''', there is a copula <math>\tilde{C}</math> such that <math>\tilde{C}(u) = W(u)</math>. However, ''W'' is a copula only in two dimensions, in which case it corresponds to countermonotonic random variables.
In two dimensions, i.e. the bivariate case, the Fréchet–Hoeffding Theorem states : <math>\max(u+v-1,0) \leq C(u,v) \leq \min\{u,v\}</math>
==Families of copulas==
Several families of copulas have been described.
===Gaussian copula=== [[File:Copula gaussian.svg|thumb|Cumulative and density distribution of Gaussian copula with ''ρ'' = 0.4]]
The Gaussian copula is a distribution over the unit cube <math>[0,1]^d</math>. It is constructed from a [[multivariate normal distribution]] over <math>\mathbb{R}^d</math> by using the [[probability integral transform]].
For a given [[correlation matrix]] <math>R\in[-1, 1]^{d\times d}</math>, the Gaussian copula with parameter matrix <math>R</math> can be written as :<math> C_R^{\text{Gauss}}(u) = \Phi_R\left(\Phi^{-1}(u_1),\dots, \Phi^{-1}(u_d) \right), </math> where <math>\Phi^{-1}</math> is the inverse cumulative distribution function of a standard normal and <math>\Phi_R</math> is the joint cumulative distribution function of a multivariate normal distribution with mean vector zero and covariance matrix equal to the correlation matrix <math>R</math>. While there is no simple analytical formula for the copula function, <math>C_R^{\text{Gauss}}(u)</math>, it can be upper or lower bounded, and approximated using numerical integration.<ref name="bo16">{{cite journal|last1=Botev|first1=Z. I.|title=The normal law under linear restrictions: simulation and estimation via minimax tilting|journal=Journal of the Royal Statistical Society, Series B|date=2016|doi=10.1111/rssb.12162|arxiv=1603.04166}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://cran.r-project.org/package=TruncatedNormal|title=TruncatedNormal: Truncated Multivariate Normal|first=Zdravko I.|last=Botev|date=10 November 2015|publisher=|via=R-Packages}}</ref> The density can be written as<ref>{{cite journal |first=Philipp |last=Arbenz |year=2013 |title=Bayesian Copulae Distributions, with Application to Operational Risk Management—Some Comments |journal=Methodology and Computing in Applied Probability |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=105–108 |doi=10.1007/s11009-011-9224-0 }}</ref> :<math> c_R^{\text{Gauss}}(u) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\det{R}}}\exp\left(-\frac{1}{2} \begin{pmatrix}\Phi^{-1}(u_1)\\ \vdots \\ \Phi^{-1}(u_d)\end{pmatrix}^T \cdot \left(R^{-1}-I\right) \cdot \begin{pmatrix}\Phi^{-1}(u_1)\\ \vdots \\ \Phi^{-1}(u_d)\end{pmatrix} \right), </math> where <math>\mathbf{I}</math> is the identity matrix.
===Archimedean copulas===
Archimedean copulas are an associative class of copulas. Most common Archimedean copulas admit an explicit formula, something not possible for instance for the Gaussian copula. In practice, Archimedean copulas are popular because they allow modeling dependence in arbitrarily high dimensions with only one parameter, governing the strength of dependence.
A copula '''C''' is called Archimedean if it admits the representation<ref name="Nelsen 2006">{{cite book |last=Nelsen |first=R. B. |year=2006 |title=An Introduction to Copulas, Second Edition |publisher=Springer Science+Business Media Inc. |location=New York, NY 10013, USA |isbn=978-1-4419-2109-3 }}</ref>
:<math> C(u_1,\dots,u_d;\theta) = \psi^{[-1]}\left(\psi(u_1;\theta)+\cdots+\psi(u_d;\theta);\theta\right) </math>
where <math>\psi\!:[0,1]\times\Theta \rightarrow [0,\infty)</math> is a continuous, strictly decreasing and convex function such that <math>\psi(1;\theta)=0</math>. <math>\theta</math> is a parameter within some parameter space <math>\Theta</math>. <math>\psi</math> is the so-called generator function and <math>\psi^{[-1]}</math> is its pseudo-inverse defined by
:<math> \psi^{[-1]}(t;\theta) = \left\{\begin{array}{ll} \psi^{-1}(t;\theta) & \mbox{if }0 \leq t \leq \psi(0;\theta) \\ 0 & \mbox{if }\psi(0;\theta) \leq t \leq\infty. \end{array}\right. </math>
Moreover, the above formula for '''C''' yields a copula for <math>\psi^{-1}</math> if and only if <math>\psi^{-1}</math> is [[d-monotone function|d-monotone]] on <math>[0,\infty)</math>.<ref>{{cite journal |last=McNeil |first=A. J. |last2=Nešlehová |first2=J. |year=2009 |title=Multivariate Archimedean copulas, ''d''-monotone functions and <math>\mathit{l}</math>1-norm symmetric distributions |journal=[[Annals of Statistics]] |volume=37 |issue=5b |pages=3059–3097 |doi=10.1214/07-AOS556 |arxiv=0908.3750 }}</ref> That is, if it is <math>d-2</math> times differentiable and the derivatives satisfy
:<math> (-1)^k\psi^{-1,(k)}(t;\theta) \geq 0 </math>
for all <math>t\geq 0</math> and <math>k=0,1,\dots,d-2</math> and <math>(-1)^{d-2}\psi^{-1,(d-2)}(t;\theta)</math> is nonincreasing and [[convex function|convex]].
